title: Labrador
text:
Statistics Lab: One-Sample t-Test
Objective
Students will: ‚Ä¢ Conduct and interpret a one-sample t-test in R (or another platform you prefer). ‚Ä¢ Compare their sample data to a known or hypothesized population mean. ‚Ä¢ Communicate their findings in APA-style format.

title: Labrador
text:
1. Concept Refresher (5‚Äì10 minutes)
Prompt: ‚ÄúSometimes we want to know if a group we‚Äôre studying is different from the general population ‚Äî but we only have one group‚Äôs data. The one-sample t-test helps us test whether our sample mean differs significantly from a known or hypothesized mean.‚Äù
Example questions to warm up: ‚Ä¢ What does the t-test compare? ‚Ä¢ What does the null hypothesis say in this context? ‚Ä¢ How does sample size affect the t statistic?

title: Labrador
section: 2. Example Scenario Ideas (Pick one or rotate by section)
text:
2. Example Scenario Ideas (Pick one or rotate by section)
Each scenario includes a population mean and invites students to test a claim:
Theme Scenario Population Mean (Œº‚ÇÄ) Variable Example üç´ Fun & Food The average American eats 12 pounds of chocolate per year. Is our class different? 12 chocolate_pounds üì± Technology On average, college students spend 4 hours/day on their phone. Is our sample higher? 4 hours_per_day üí§ Sleep The CDC recommends 8 hours of sleep per night. Does our sample get less? 8 sleep_hours üò¨ Anxiety National anxiety scale mean = 50 (SD = 10). Is our class more anxious? 50 anxiety_score

title: Labrador
text:
3. Data Collection (10‚Äì15 minutes)
Option 1: Live data collection Have students submit quick responses via Google Form or Qualtrics (e.g., ‚ÄúHow many hours of sleep did you get last night?‚Äù). Export as a .csv.
Option 2: Simulated dataset Provide a dataset such as:

title: Labrador
text:
4. Analysis (15‚Äì20 minutes)
Step 1: State hypotheses ‚Ä¢ H‚ÇÄ: Œº = Œº‚ÇÄ ‚Ä¢ H‚ÇÅ: Œº ‚â† Œº‚ÇÄ
Step 2: Run the test in R



    One Sample t-test

data:  sleep_data$sleep_hours
t = -5.2258, df = 29, p-value = 1.354e-05
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 8
95 percent confidence interval:
 6.827916 7.487297
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 7.157607 


Step 3: Interpret the output ‚Ä¢ t-value ‚Ä¢ df ‚Ä¢ p-value ‚Ä¢ 95% confidence interval ‚Ä¢ Direction of difference
Step 4: APA write-up example
Students in our sample (M = 7.2, SD = 0.9) reported significantly less sleep than the CDC‚Äôs recommended 8 hours, t(29) = -4.67, p < .001.

title: Labrador
text:
5. Discussion Questions
1.  What does the negative t-value indicate?
2.  What would happen if the sample were larger but had the same mean?
3.  How does the confidence interval help confirm your conclusion?
4.  Can a non-significant result still be meaningful? Why or why not?

title: Labrador
text:
6. Optional Extension
‚Ä¢   Effect Size: Calculate Cohen‚Äôs d manually or using:


[1] -0.9540911


‚Ä¢   Visualization: Show how the sample mean compares to the population mean with a density plot or boxplot.

title: Labrador
text:
Deliverable
A short lab report (or RMarkdown/Quarto doc) including: 1. Stated hypotheses 2. Output and interpretation 3. APA-style results section 4. Visual (optional) 5. Reflection question: ‚ÄúWhat does your result suggest about your sample?‚Äù

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Recap
How Did We Get Here!

We began the semester by discussing how to define and measure psychological and abstract concepts.
We explored different types of variables and scales of measurement, learning how data can be categorized or quantified.
We used the normal distribution to examine variability and to understand how scores can be assigned probability values using standardized (z) scores.
Through sampling theory, we saw how many possible samples create a distribution of sample means, centered around the true population mean.
If we can estimate the probability that a sample mean came from a particular distribution, can we also estimate whether it came from the null or the alternative hypothesis?

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
From Probability to Decision-Making

Once we know how likely a sample mean is to occur, we can begin to make decisions about what that likelihood means.
We introduced two competing ideas:

Null hypothesis (\(H_0\)): No real difference or effect.
Alternative hypothesis (\(H_1\)): A true difference or effect exists.

Because samples vary, we can never be 100% certain‚Äîonly confident to a degree.

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Errors in Estimation
Type I and II Error

That degree of confidence is defined by Œ± (alpha), our threshold for error when rejecting \(H_0\).
\(\beta\) (beta) represents the probability of missing a real effect (failing to reject \(H_0\) when \(H_1\) is true).
These lead to two types of decision errors:

Type I error (\(\alpha\)): Finding a difference that isn‚Äôt really there. (False Positive)
Type II error (\(\beta\)): Missing a difference that actually exists. (False Negative)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
The Truth Table








Decision Outcomes in Hypothesis Testing



\[H_0\text{ True}\]
\[H_0\text{ False}\]




\[\text{Reject }H_0\]
\[\text{Type I Error }(\alpha)\]
\[\text{Correct Decision}\\1-\beta\]


\[\text{Fail to Reject } H_0\]
\[\text{Correct Decision}\\1-\alpha\]
\[\text{Type II Error } (\beta)\]

title: One-Sample T-Test
text: R

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Before We Compare Means‚Ä¶

Every statistical test is about making a decision:

Is our result likely due to chance, or does it reflect a real difference?

Two key players in this decision:

Œ± (alpha): our threshold for how much error we‚Äôll tolerate (Type I Error)
Œ≤ (beta): the risk of missing a real effect (Type II Error)

Balancing Œ± and Œ≤ helps us manage:

False alarms (rejecting a true null)
Missed detections (failing to reject a false null)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Why Compare Means?

We often want to test whether a sample mean differs from a known population mean.
The one-sample t-test helps determine if the sample mean is significantly different from the hypothesized population mean.
Example scenarios:

Does the average exam score in a class differ from a national average of 75?
Do people‚Äôs reaction times differ from a published standard of 250ms?
Tests against the midpoint of a scale

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
The t-test
Three Types - Three Cases



One-Sample T-Test

\(t=\frac{\bar{x}-\mu}{\sigma} |\frac{\bar{x}}{s/\sqrt(n)}\)




Paired-Samples T Test

\(t=\frac{\bar{D}}{\sigma_{\bar{D}}}|\frac{\bar{D}}{s_{\bar{D}}/\sqrt(n)}\)




Independent-Samples T Test

\(t = \frac{\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2}{n_1} + \frac{s_2^2}{n_2}}}\)




We use the sample standard deviation (\(s\)) to estimate the standard error (\(s/\sqrt{n}\)) since population œÉ is typically unknown.
In all cases, variation in statistical significance factors in degrees of freedom (df)

Accounts for variability in sampling

title: One-Sample T-Test
text: The t-distribution

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Assumptions of the One-Sample t-Test

The data are continuous (interval or ratio scale).
The sample is randomly selected.
The data are normally distributed (or the sample size is large enough for the Central Limit Theorem to apply).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
The One-Sample t-Test Formula
The test statistic is calculated as:






One Sample T-Test


\(\large{t = \frac{\color{red}{\bar{x}}-\color{blue}{\mu}}{\color{orange}{\sigma}}}\)



Where:

\(\color{red}{\bar{x}}\) = sample mean
\(\color{blue}{\mu}\) = population mean (null hypothesis value)
\(\color{orange}{\sigma}{\text{ or }}SE\)

\(s\) = sample standard deviation
\(\sqrt{n}\) = sample size

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Hypothesis Testing Steps

Set Hypotheses

Define both the Null and Alternative

Collect Sample Data:

Use the appropriate sampling method and collect needed data*

Compute the t-Statistic:

Conduct the correct t-test

Compare to Critical Value:

Use the t-statistic, sample-size, and alpha level to determine statistical significance.

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Hypothesis Testing Steps
Manual

Set Hypotheses:

\(H_0\): The average exam score is 75 (\(\mu = 75\)).
\(H_A\): The average exam score is not 75 (\(\mu \neq 75\)).

Collect Sample Data:

Sample size: \(n = 20\)
Sample mean: \(\bar{x} = 78\)
Sample standard deviation: \(s = 5\)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Hypothesis Testing Steps
Manual

Compute the t-Statistic:

\(t = \frac{78 - 75}{\frac{5}{\sqrt{20}}} = \frac{3}{1.118} = 2.68\)

Compare to Critical Value:

Using a \(\alpha = 0.05\) level and df = 19, critical
\(t_{critical} = \pm 2.093\).
Since \(2.68 > 2.093\), we reject \(H_0\).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Hypothesis Testing Steps
Programmatic


Code
library(dplyr)
library(broom)
library(gt)

# Using Functions
n = 20
m = 78
mu = 75
s = 5
dat <- rnorm(n,m,s) |> round(0)
t.test(dat,mu = mu) |> 
  tidy() |> 
  rename(
    M = estimate,
    t = statistic,
    df = parameter,
    p = p.value
  ) |>
  gt(rowname_col = "method") |> 
  fmt_auto() |> 
  opt_row_striping()









M
t
p
df
conf.low
conf.high
alternative




One Sample t-test
77.1
1.712
0.103
19¬†
74.533
79.667
two.sided







Code
# Manually
(m-mu)/(5/sqrt(n))


[1] 2.683282

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Reporting Results
APA-style:

A one-sample t-test was conducted to compare exam scores to the national average of 75. Results showed a significant difference, t(19) = 2.68, p < .05, indicating that students scored significantly higher than the national average.


What kind of test?
What is being compared?
Is it significant?
What are the test results?

What kind of test?

Is it significant?
What are the test results?

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Interpreting Results
Sample Summary Table

A significant result (\(p < .05\)) suggests that the sample mean is different from the population mean.
A non-significant result (\(p > .05\)) means we fail to reject \(H_0\) (no evidence of a difference).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text: Visualizing Data

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Exam Scores vs.¬†National Average
Programmatic

A professor wants to test if students in their class scored differently from the national average of 75 on an exam. A sample of 25 students has a mean score of 78 with a standard deviation of 10.



Code
# For Reproduceability
set.seed(131)

# Generate a random dataset with mean of 78, sd of 10
x <- rnorm(25,78,10)

t.test(
  x,
  # Specify that the mean to test against is 75
  mu = 75
  )



    One Sample t-test

data:  x
t = 1.1505, df = 24, p-value = 0.2613
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 75
95 percent confidence interval:
 73.33317 80.86545
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 77.09931

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Exam Scores vs.¬†National Average
Manual

A professor wants to test if students in their class scored differently from the national average of 75 on an exam. A sample of 25 students has a mean score of 78 with a standard deviation of 10.


Hypotheses

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): ( \(\mu = 75\) ) (no difference)
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): ( \(\mu \neq 75\) ) (scores differ)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Exam Scores vs.¬†National Average
Manual

Using the one-sample t-test formula:

\(t = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu}{\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}} |t = \frac{78 - 75}{\frac{10}{\sqrt{25}}} = \frac{3}{2} = 1.5\)

For df = 24 (25-1), the critical value at Œ± = .05 (two-tailed) is ¬±2.064.
Since 1.5 < 2.064, we fail to reject \(H_0\).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
APA Reporting

A one-sample t-test was conducted to determine whether students‚Äô exam scores differed from the national average (M = 75). Results were not statistically significant, ( t(24) = 1.5, p > .05 ), indicating that students performed similarly to the national average.

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Daily Coffee Consumption

A coffee company claims that people drink an average of 3 cups of coffee per day. A researcher samples 16 individuals, finding a mean of 2.5 cups and a standard deviation of 1 cup.


Hypotheses

Null Hypothesis (\(H_0\)): \(\mu = 3\)
Alternative Hypothesis (\(H_A\)): \(\mu < 3\) (people drink less)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Daily Coffee Consumption
Manual

A coffee company claims that people drink an average of 3 cups of coffee per day. A researcher samples 16 individuals, finding a mean of 2.5 cups and a standard deviation of 1 cup.


Calculation

\(t = \frac{2.5 - 3}{1 / \sqrt{16}} = \frac{-0.5}{0.25} = -2.0\)

For df = 15 (16-1), the critical t-value for a one-tailed test at Œ± = .05 is -1.753.
Since -2.0 < -1.753, we reject \(H_0\).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Daily Coffee Consumption
Programmatic

A coffee company claims that people drink an average of 3 cups of coffee per day. A researcher samples 16 individuals, finding a mean of 2.5 cups and a standard deviation of 1 cup.



Code
# For Reproduceability
set.seed(131)

# Generate a random dataset with mean of 78, sd of 10
x <- rnorm(16,2.5,1)

t.test(
  x,
  # Specify that the mean to test against is 75
  mu = 3
  )



    One Sample t-test

data:  x
t = -2.2081, df = 15, p-value = 0.04322
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 3
95 percent confidence interval:
 2.068607 2.983542
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 2.526075

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
APA Reporting

A one-sample t-test was conducted to test whether daily coffee consumption was lower than the reported average of 3 cups. Results showed a significant difference, t(15)=-2.0,p< .05, suggesting that people consume significantly fewer cups of coffee per day than reported.

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Sleep Duration Among College Students

A health researcher believes college students sleep less than 7 hours per night. A sample of 30 students reports a mean of 6.5 hours with a standard deviation of 1.2 hours.


Hypotheses

Null Hypothesis \(H_0\): \(\mu = 7\)
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_1\): \(\mu < 7\)

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Sleep Duration Among College Students
Manual

A health researcher believes college students sleep less than 7 hours per night. A sample of 30 students reports a mean of 6.5 hours with a standard deviation of 1.2 hours.


Calculation

\(t = \frac{6.5 - 7}{1.2 / \sqrt{30}} = \frac{-0.5}{0.219} = -2.28\)

For df = 29, the critical t-value for a one-tailed test at Œ± = .05 is -1.699.
Since -2.28 < -1.699, we reject (H_0).

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
Sleep Duration Among College Students
Programmatic

A health researcher believes college students sleep less than 7 hours per night. A sample of 30 students reports a mean of 6.5 hours with a standard deviation of 1.2 hours.



Code
# For Reproduceability
set.seed(728)

# Generate a random dataset with mean of 78, sd of 10
x <- rnorm(30,6.5,1.2) |> round(0)

t.test(
  x,
  # Specify that the mean to test against is 75
  mu = 7
  )



    One Sample t-test

data:  x
t = -2.5381, df = 29, p-value = 0.01678
alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 7
95 percent confidence interval:
 5.976708 6.889959
sample estimates:
mean of x 
 6.433333

title: One-Sample T-Test
text:
APA Reporting

A one-sample t-test was conducted to test whether college students sleep fewer than 7 hours per night. Results were statistically significant, t(29) = -2.28, p < .05, indicating that students get significantly less sleep than the recommended amount.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation
What do you know about correlations?


Correlation ‚â† Causation
r
Positive correlation: variables move together

As one goes up, the other goes up.
As one goes down, the other goes down.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation
Assesses how two variables move in relation to one another.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


What are measures of dispersion?
Measures of how spread out the data are, how much participants differ.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


How do we measure dispersion when we were looking at one variable?
Standard deviation
Variance

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


Univariate = one variable
Bivariate = two variables
Multivariate = more than two variables

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


Univariate = one variable
Bivariate = two variables
Multivariate = more than two variables

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


Univariate measures of dispersion?

Standard deviation: How different are participants from the average?

Bivariate measures of dispersion:

Covariance
How much variation in one variable is the same in another variable?
Do the variables vary in the same way?

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Measures of Dispersion


Univariate measures of dispersion?
Standard deviation: Height M = 5'6", s = 2 inches
Bivariate measures of dispersion:

Covariance: Does the spread-out-ness of height overlap with the spread-out-ness of weight?

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance

Professor Brocker wants to know if how many cups of coffee a professor drinks daily impacts their happiness. She asks 50 professors how many cups they have in a typical day and then has them rate their happiness on a scale of 1 to 10.



Variable 1: Number of Cups of Coffee = continuous
Variable 2: Happiness = continuous

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
We could:


Find the variance of each variable
Find the covariance of the two variables together

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Covariance refers to how two continuous variables vary in tandem.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Covariance refers to how two variables vary together:


Generally, if cups of coffee goes up, what does happiness tend to do?
Generally, if happiness goes up, what does cups of coffee tend to do?

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance

Professor Brocker wants to know if how many cups of coffee a professor drinks daily impacts their happiness. She asks 50 professors how many cups they have in a typical day and then has them rate their happiness on a scale of 1 to 10.



Variable 1: Number of Cups of Coffee
Variable 2: Happiness



\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X}(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Well, well, well‚ÄìWe Meet Again

\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X}(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]


\[
s^2 = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})^2}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance

\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X}(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]


\[
s^2 = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})^2}{N-1} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(X-\bar{X})}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
The variance of a variable is the covariance of that variable with itself.

\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X}(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Covariance is the variance of two variables together‚Ä¶ how they move together.

\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Let‚Äôs break it down.


Find the mean of each variable.



\[\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma(x)}{n}\] \[\bar{Y} = \frac{\Sigma(Y)}{n}\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Let‚Äôs break it down.


Find the mean of each variable.
Subtract the mean of x from each x value.
Subtract the mean of y from each y value.



\[(X-\bar{X})\] \[(Y-\bar{Y})\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Let‚Äôs break it down.


Find the mean of each variable.
Subtract the mean of x from each x value.
Subtract the mean of y from each y value.
Multiple the deviation scores of x with the deviation scores of y.


\[(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Let‚Äôs break it down.


Find the mean of each variable.
Subtract the mean of x from each x value.
Subtract the mean of y from each y value.
Multiple the deviation scores of x with the deviation scores of y.
Sum the products of the deviation scores.



\[\sum(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Let‚Äôs break it down.


Find the mean of each variable.
Subtract the mean of x from each x value.
Subtract the mean of y from each y value.
Multiple the deviation scores of x with the deviation scores of y.
Sum the products of the deviation scores.
Divide by N-1.



\[\frac{\sum(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Covariance
Covariance is the bivariate equivalent of variance.


What does the covariance tell us?
What did the variance tell us?

Not much because it was inflated.

For it to be useful, we had to standardize it.



\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation


Correlation is the standardized covariance.
Correlation is the bivariate version of the standard deviation.
To calculate the correlation, we divide the covariance by the standard deviation of x multipled by the standard deviation of y.



\[\frac{cov_{xy}}{(SD_x)(SD_y)}\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation

\[
COV_{XY} = \frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{N-1}
\] \[\frac{cov_{xy}}{(SD_x)(SD_y)}\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation
Calculating Correlation:

\[
\frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{(SD_x)(SD_y)(N-1)}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation
Correlation is the bivariate version of the standard deviation.

\[
\frac{\Sigma(X-\bar{X})(Y-\bar{Y})}{(SD_x)(SD_y)(N-1)}
\]

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation


Correlation is bounded between -1 and +1.
Closer to -1 is a negative correlation.
Closer to +1 is a positive correlation.
Closer to 0 means no correlation.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text: Correlation

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation
This is the Pearson Product-Moment Correlation (Pearson, 1895).


The sign indicates the direction.
The number indicates the magnitude/strength of the relationship.

0.1 is a small correlation
0.3 is a moderate correlation
0.5 or higher is a large correlation

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation


Correlation is written as r
If we square r, we get \(R^2\)
\(R^2\) is always positive
\(R^2\) refers to:

The amount of x accounted for by y.
The amount of y accounted for by x.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation and \(R^2\)
Example

Students grades in MTH 110 and their grades in correlation at r = 0.3



Moderate correlation
How much of your grade is accounted for by your MTH 110 grade?
0.3 x 0.3 = 0.09
\(R^2\) = 9% of your grade is explained by your MTH 110 grade.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text: Interpreting Correlation

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Interpreting Correlation


We don‚Äôt use the words caused/resulting from.
When reporting r: ‚ÄúAs x goes up, y tends to go up.‚Äù
When reporting \(R^2\): ‚Äúz% of x is accounted for by y.‚Äù

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Reporting correlation
Correlation Matrix


In the Method, we report descriptive statistics about our variables (M, s).
It is common to refer readers to a table where they can look at correlations between the variables.
Why might this be important?

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation Matrix
Table 1 in a paper is typically a combination of descriptive stats AND correlation matrix, like this:






Ms123



Age20.91.761----

Song 14.211.2.031--

Song 26.422.18.65**-.34*1

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Correlation Matrix
Table 1 in a paper is typically a combination of descriptive stats AND correlation matrix, like this:






Ms123



Age20.91.761-.03.65**

Song 14.211.2-.031-.34*

Song 26.422.18.65**-.34*1

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Reporting Calculation
Example 1

In a psychology experiment, researchers collected data on the number of hours spent studying and the scores on a final exam for 50 students. Below is a scatterplot showing the relationship between the two variables.













Based on the scatterplot, describe the strength and direction of the relationship between hours spent studying and exam scores. Would you say the correlation is weak, moderate, or strong? Is it positive or negative?

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Reporting Calculation
Example 1












Suppose the computed Pearson correlation coefficient is r = 0.85 . Explain what this value indicates about the relationship between the two variables.

title: Covariance & Correlation
text:
Reporting Calculation
Example 2

Using the same data from the previous question, the researchers fit a linear regression model to predict exam scores from the number of hours spent studying. The \(R^2\) value for the model is 0.72.


What does an \(R^2\) value of 0.72 tell you about how well hours spent studying explain the variance in exam scores? What percentage of the variance is explained by the model, and what percentage remains unexplained?
Imagine you are the researcher. Based on the \(R^2\) value of 0.72, would you consider study time to be a good predictor of exam performance? Why or why not?

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text: Sampling Theory

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text: Sampling Theory

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Sampling Theory
Setting alpha to 0.05, puts the critical value at a point where 5% of the null distribution‚Äôs area is to the right of it.

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Inferential Statistics
Applied to Independent Groups

Our goal is still to test whether a difference is likely due to chance
With independnet samples, chance variation now includes differences between individuals in both groups.

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
T-tests

IV must be nominal and have only 2 categories

Using experimental versus control
Any two categories (bad/good)

DV must be continuous

Scale of 1 to 10
Count

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Independent Samples t-test
Example

The experimental group drinks caffeinated coffee. The control group drinks decaf. I ask both groups to complete a survey to measure their happiness on a scale of 1 to 10.


The experimental group has a mean happiness score of 8
The control group mean happiness score of 6


Is the group that drank coffee significantly happier than the control group?

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text: Independent samples t-test

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Independent samples t-test
To compare the means we need to know:

Between group variance: how much the answers from the experimental group differ from the control group.
Within group variance: how much the answers of all participants differ from one another.

Random sampling:

The data is randomly sampled from a population¬†

Independence:

Each group must be made up of independent observations.

Homogeneity of variance:

Variance should be equal across groups (tested with Levene‚Äôs Test)

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Why Do We Care?
We need the Levene‚Äôs Test, because if the variance from the experimental group is not equal to the variance of the control group, we have to use a different formula for the pooled standard deviation.

A significant Levene‚Äôs Test means a significant difference in the variances.

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Independent samples t-test: SPSS
Interpreting Results
If the Levene‚Äôs Test is significant, use the t value from the second row and its corresponding significance

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Does chocolate improve concentration?
Design Summary

50 undergraduate students from XYZ University were randomly assigned to one of two groups. One group received a small piece of chocolate (70% dark cocoa) to consume before completing a 10-minute concentration task. The other group received no chocolate. The task measured sustained attention and was scored on a 0‚Äì20 scale.


IV: Chocolate (Yes vs.¬†No)

DV: Concentration task score

Design: Between-subjects, randomized

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text: Example 2: Music and Study Efficiency

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Does instrumental music improve studying?

Design Summary
40 students participated in a study examining how background music affects studying. Participants were randomly assigned to study a short academic text under one of two conditions: instrumental music or silence. After 15 minutes of study time, they completed a 10-item multiple-choice quiz.


IV: Study condition (Instrumental music vs.¬†Silence)

DV: Quiz performance (number of correct answers)

Design: Between-subjects, randomized

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Example 3: Phone Use and Sleep
Does bedtime phone use affect sleep?

Design Summary
80 students from XYZ University took part in a study on sleep and cell phone use. Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions. One group was instructed to avoid phone use for 30 minutes before bed, while the other used their phones as normal. The next morning, all students rated their sleep quality on a 1‚Äì10 scale.


IV: Phone use before bed (Yes vs.¬†No)

DV: Sleep quality rating (1 = poor, 10 = excellent)

Design: Between-subjects, randomized

title: Independent Samples T-Test
section: Does bedtime phone use affect sleep?
text:
Does bedtime phone use affect sleep?

Design Summary
80 students from XYZ University took part in a study on sleep and cell phone use. Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions. One group was instructed to avoid phone use for 30 minutes before bed, while the other used their phones as normal. The next morning, all students rated their sleep quality on a 1‚Äì10 scale.


IV: Phone use before bed (Yes vs.¬†No)

DV: Sleep quality rating (1 = poor, 10 = excellent)

Design: Between-subjects, randomized

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Introduction to Paired Samples t-Test
What is a Paired Samples t-Test?

A statistical method used to compare the means of two related groups.
Commonly used when measuring the same group before and after an intervention or over two different conditions.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Purpose of Paired Samples t-Test
Why Use Paired Samples t-Test?

To determine if there is a statistically significant difference between two related group means.
Useful in psychology for assessing changes due to an intervention, therapy, or experiment.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Formula for Paired Samples t-Test
Mathematical Representation

Formula: \(\large{t = \frac{\bar{d}}{{s_{\bar{d}}}/\sqrt{n}}} = \frac{\bar{d}}{\sigma}\)

\(\bar{d}\): Mean of the differences between paired observations.
\(s_d\): Standard deviation of the differences.
\(n\): Number of pairs.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Theoretical Formula Explanation
Understanding Each Component

Difference Mean \(\bar{d}\):

Average of the differences between paired scores.

Standard Deviation of Differences \(s_d\):

Indicates how much individual differences deviate from the mean difference.

Sample Size \(n\):

Number of pairs, affecting the significance of results.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Application of Paired Samples t-Test
When to Apply This Test

Pretest-Posttest Design

Measure changes in the same group over time.

Matched Pairs

Compare two related groups, such as twins or matched participants.

Repeated Measures

Test the same group under different conditions or at different times.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired Samples t-Test
Application in Psychology Research

A psychologist measures stress levels of a group before and after a mindfulness program. Participants first answer a stress suvrvey, next they participate in a mindfulness exercise. After the exercise, their stress scores are measured again and compared.

Steps:

State the Null and Alternative Hypothesis
Calculate the difference between pre- and post-intervention scores.
Find the mean \(\bar{d}\) and standard deviation \(s_d\) of the differences.
Apply the formula to calculate the t-value and check for significance.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired Samples t-Test
Application in Psychology Research

A psychologist measures stress levels of a group before and after a mindfulness program. Participants first answer a stress suvrvey, next they participate in a mindfulness exercise. After the exercise, their stress scores are measured again and compared.


State the Null and Alternative Hypothesis

\(H_0\): There will be no difference in stress before or after the mindfulness exercise

\(H_0: \mu_\text{post} = \mu_\text{pre}\)

\(H_A\): There will be a decrease in stress after the mindfulness exercise

\(H_A: \mu_\text{post} < \mu_\text{pre}\)

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired Samples t-Test
Application in Psychology Research

A psychologist measures stress levels of a group before and after a mindfulness program. Participants first answer a stress suvrvey, next they participate in a mindfulness exercise. After the exercise, their stress scores are measured again and compared.



Code
# Load Packages
library(dplyr)
library(broom)
library(gt)

# Random Seed
set.seed(20)

# Create data
data <- 
  tibble(
  # Make a variable, `group` with 30 T1 and 30 T2
  group = rep(c("Time One","Time Two"), each = 30),
  # Make a variable, `score` with 60 scores
  score = c(rnorm(30,8,2),rnorm(30,4,1)) |> round(0)
) 

data |> 
  gt_preview() |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  tab_options(
    table.font.size = 15,
    table.width = pct(40)
    ) |> 
    tab_style(
    style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_column_labels()
  )

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired Samples t-Test
Compare Scores

Calculate the difference between pre-mindfullness stress and post-mindfullness scores.



Code
data_new <- 
  data |> 
  group_by(group) |> 
  mutate(
    id = paste0("Participant ",row_number()),
    group = ifelse(stringr::str_detect(group,"One"),"T1","T2")) |> 
  tidyr::pivot_wider(
                     names_from = group,
                     values_from = score
                     ) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  mutate(
    D = T2-T1,
    Dfi = ifelse(stringr::str_detect(D,"^-"),paste0("(",D,")"),D)
  )

data_new |> 
  select(-D) |> 
  gt_preview() |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_options(
    table.font.size = 32,
    table.width = pct(70)
    ) |> 
    tab_style(
    style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_column_labels()
  )

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired Samples t-Test
Construct the Formula (Manually)

Find the mean \(\bar{d}\) and standard deviation \(s_d\) of the differences.
Apply the formula to calculate the t-value and check for significance.
\(\large{t = \frac{d}{{s_d}/\sqrt{n}} =  \frac{-3.26}{2.083/\sqrt{30}} = (-8.57)}\)

title: Paired Samples T-Test
Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired T-Tests
Visualizing Results




Code
library(ggplot2)
library(viridis)

data |> 
  ggplot(aes(group, score, fill = group)) + 
  stat_summary(
    fun = "mean",
    geom = "bar",
    width = .4
  ) + 
  stat_summary(
    fun.data = "mean_se",
    geom = "errorbar",
    width=.2
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "\nTesting Time",
    y = "Stress Score\n",
    fill = "Time",
    title = "Mindfulness Intervention and Stress Levels",
    subtitle = "Stress scores decrease after exposure to mindfulness treatment.\n",
    caption = "t(29) = 8.58, p <.001, 95% CI [2.49, 4.04]"
  ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title.position =  "plot",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    panel.grid.major = element_blank()
  ) +
  scale_fill_viridis(
    discrete = TRUE, 
    option = "H",
    alpha = .8
    )












Code
library(ggplot2)
library(viridis)

data |> 
  ggplot(aes(group, score, color = group)) + 
  geom_jitter(aes(alpha = .2)) + 
  stat_summary(
    fun.data = "mean_se",
    geom = "line",
    group = 1,
    color = "black"
  ) + 
  stat_summary(
    fun.data = "mean_se",
    geom = "errorbar",
    width = .1
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "\nTesting Time",
    y = "Stress Score\n",
    color = "Time",
    title = "Mindfulness Intervention and Stress Levels",
    subtitle = "Stress scores decrease after exposure to mindfulness treatment.\n",
    caption = "t(29) = 8.58, p <.001, 95% CI [2.49, 4.04]"
  ) + 
  theme(
    plot.title.position =  "plot",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "none"
  ) +
    scale_color_viridis(
    discrete = TRUE, 
    option = "H",
    alpha = .8
    )

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Paired T-Tests
Visualizing Results: Option 2

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Summary of Paired Samples t-Test
Key Takeaways

Paired samples t-tests are ideal for comparing two related groups.
They help determine if interventions or conditions produce significant changes.
Remember to check assumptions: normality of differences and appropriate pairing.

Differences are normally distributed.

Check using histogram, QQ plot, or Shapiro-Wilk test.

Pairs are dependent (related measures).

Same participants or matched pairs.

No major outliers in the differences.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Effect Size: Cohen‚Äôs d
Why Report Effect Size?

Statistical significance (p) tells us if there is a difference.
Effect size tells us how big that difference is.
\(d = \frac{\bar{d}}{s_d}\)

\(\bar{d}\) = mean difference between paired scores

\(s_d\) = standard deviation of the differences




Code
tibble(
    `Cohen's d` = c(0.20, 0.50, 0.80),
    Interpretation = c("Small effect", "Medium effect", "Large effect")
) %>%
    gt() |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  tab_options(
    table.width = pct(50),
    table.font.size = 22
  )








Cohen's d
Interpretation




0.2
Small effect


0.5
Medium effect


0.8
Large effect

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Interpreting Results

We found a statistically significant decrease in stress (p < .001).

The effect size (d = 1.56) indicates a large change.

Combining significance and effect size gives us a fuller picture of the data.


Always ask: Is this difference not just statistically, but practically meaningful?

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Connection to the One-Sample t-Test

Recall that the paired-samples t-test is essentially a one-sample t-test on the difference scores.
We‚Äôre testing whether the **mean difference \(bar{d}\) is significantly different from 0.

title: Paired Samples T-Test
text:
Example Datasets


Code
library(tidyverse)

set.seed(101)
# Paired Samples t-Test: Pre vs. Post Stress Scores
ex_1 <- tibble(
  ID = 1:30,
  Stress_Pre = rnorm(30, mean = 20, sd = 4),
  Stress_Post = rnorm(30, mean = 16, sd = 4)
)

set.seed(102)

# Example Dataset 2 ‚Äî Paired Samples t-Test: Reaction Time Before/After Music
ex_2 <- tibble(
  ID = 1:25,
  RT_NoMusic = rnorm(25, mean = 520, sd = 60),
  RT_Music = rnorm(25, mean = 500, sd = 55)
)

set.seed(103)

# Example Dataset 3 ‚Äî Independent Samples t-Test: Caffeine vs. Placebo Alertness
ex_3 <- tibble(
  Group = rep(c("Caffeine", "Placebo"), each = 20),
  Alertness = c(
    rnorm(20, mean = 75, sd = 8),
    rnorm(20, mean = 68, sd = 8)
  )
)

set.seed(104)

# Example Dataset 4 ‚Äî Independent Samples t-Test: Online vs. In-Person Exam Scores
ex_4 <- tibble(
  Format = rep(c("Online", "InPerson"), each = 25),
  Exam_Score = c(
    rnorm(25, mean = 82, sd = 5),
    rnorm(25, mean = 79, sd = 6)
  )
)

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
From Paired to Independent Samples
Last time, we compared two related means ‚Äî the same participants measured twice (e.g., before vs.¬†after caffeine).
Now, we‚Äôll compare two unrelated means ‚Äî different participants in each group.







Paired t-test
Independent t-test




Same people
Different people


Within-subjects
Between-subjects


Reduces error (individual differences)
Must estimate error separately

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
From Paired to Independent Samples
Visual Comparison

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Sampling Theory (Recap)

Sampling theory allows us to test two unrelated group
We can compare the group means

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Independent Samples t-test Overview
Used when we compare two different groups on a continuous outcome.

Examples:

Coffee drinkers vs.¬†decaf drinkers on happiness
Students with music vs.¬†silence during study
Phone use vs.¬†no phone use before bed

Goal:

Is the mean difference between groups larger than what we‚Äôd expect by chance?

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Interpreting Levene‚Äôs Test

Levene‚Äôs Test tells us whether the assumption of equal variances holds.

If p > .05 ‚Üí use the top row** (‚ÄúEqual variances assumed‚Äù)
If p < .05 ‚Üí use the bottom row (‚ÄúEqual variances not assumed‚Äù)

Normality

Each group‚Äôs distribution should be approximately normal

title: Independent Samples T-Test
section: Let‚Äôs Apply It: Three Independent Designs
text:
Let‚Äôs Apply It: Three Independent Designs
We‚Äôll test three common between-subjects designs:
1. Chocolate and Concentration ‚Äì Experimental vs.¬†Control
2. Music and Studying ‚Äì Environmental manipulation
3. Phone Use and Sleep ‚Äì Behavioral difference

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Summary: Independent Samples t-test

Compares two independent groups
Tests whether the difference in means is significant
Uses pooled variance as the denominator
Check assumptions: independence, normality, equal variance
Commonly used in experimental designs

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Sampling Theory (Recap)

Sampling theory allows us to test two unrelated group
We can compare the group means

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Sampling Theory (Recap)

Sampling theory allows us to test two unrelated group
We can compare the group means

text:
Sampling Theory (Recap)

We can compare the group means

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Sampling Theory (Recap)

Sampling theory allows us to test two unrelated group
We can compare the group means

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Group Variance
Within and Between


To compare the means we need to know:

Between group variance: how much the answers from the experimental group differ from the control group.
Within group variance: how much the answers of all participants differ from one another.

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Formulas
Inferential statistics have both theoretical and computational formulas:

Theoretical

Formula for if we actually knew the population parameters

Computational

Formula for estimating the test statistics based solely on sample data

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Does chocolate improve concentration?



50 undergraduate students from XYZ University were randomly assigned to one of two groups. One group received a small piece of chocolate (70% dark cocoa) to consume before completing a 10-minute concentration task. The other group received no chocolate. The task measured sustained attention and was scored on a 0‚Äì20 scale.




Code
library(ggplot2)
library(gtsummary)
library(dplyr)
library(gt)
library(broom)

set.seed(42)
choco <- data.frame(
  concentration = c(rnorm(25, 15, 2), rnorm(25, 13.5, 2)),
  group = rep(c("chocolate", "no_chocolate"), each = 25)
)


# Plot
ggplot(choco, aes(x = group, y = concentration, fill = group)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = .5) +
  geom_jitter(alpha = .4) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Chocolate and Concentration",
       y = "Concentration Score", x = "")









Code
# Summary Table
t.test(concentration ~ group, 
       data = choco,
       var.equal = TRUE) %>%
  tidy() %>%
  select(-method) |> 
  rename(
    Difference = estimate,
    t = statistic,
    p = p.value,
    df = parameter,
    `95% CI Low` = conf.low,
    `95% CI High` = conf.high
  ) |> 
  mutate(p = ifelse(p<.05,"<.05",p)) |> 
  gt() |> 
  fmt_auto()








Difference
estimate1
estimate2
t
p
df
95% CI Low
95% CI High
alternative




2.393
15.375
12.982
3.708
<.05
48¬†
1.095
3.69
two.sided

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Example 2: Music and Study Efficiency
Does instrumental music improve studying?



Design Summary
40 students participated in a study examining how background music affects studying. Participants were randomly assigned to study a short academic text under one of two conditions: instrumental music or silence. After 15 minutes of study time, they completed a 10-item multiple-choice quiz.




Code
set.seed(99)
music <- 
  data.frame(
    quiz_score = c(rnorm(20, 18, 1), 
                   rnorm(20, 16.5, 1.2)),
    group = rep(c("music", "silence"), each = 20)
)

# Plot
ggplot(music, 
       aes(x = group, 
           y = quiz_score, 
           fill = group)
       ) +
  geom_violin(trim = FALSE,alpha = .4) +
  geom_jitter(
    width = 0.1, 
    alpha = 0.4
    ) +
  stat_summary(
    fun.data = "mean_se",
    geom = "errorbar",
    width = .2
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Music and Study Performance",
    y = "Quiz Score", 
    x = "")









Code
# Summary Table
  t.test(quiz_score ~ group, 
         data = music,
         ,var.equal = TRUE) %>%
  tidy() |> 
  select(-method) |> 
  rename(
    Estimate = estimate,
    t  = statistic,
    p = p.value,
    df = parameter,
    `95% CI Low` = conf.low,
    `95% CI High` = conf.high
  ) |> 
  mutate(p = ifelse(p<.05,"<.05",p)) |> 
  gt() |> 
  fmt_auto()








Estimate

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Does instrumental music improve studying?



Design Summary
40 students participated in a study examining how background music affects studying. Participants were randomly assigned to study a short academic text under one of two conditions: instrumental music or silence. After 15 minutes of study time, they completed a 10-item multiple-choice quiz.

title: Independent Samples T-Test
text:
Example 3: Phone Use and Sleep
Does bedtime phone use affect sleep?



Design Summary
80 students from XYZ University took part in a study on sleep and cell phone use. Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions. One group was instructed to avoid phone use for 30 minutes before bed, while the other used their phones as normal. The next morning, all students rated their sleep quality on a 1‚Äì10 scale.
